caption:
This photograph captures a young boy engaging in an outdoor cooking activity. The boy, who appears to be in his early teens, is using a hose to add water to a large, metal kettle filled with shellfish, which is suspended over an open fire. The scene suggests a clam cooking process, typical of outdoor seafood preparations.

The boy is attentively managing the hose, looking down at the kettle to ensure proper water addition. He wears a short-sleeved, patterned shirt featuring a geometric design and has a hairstyle typical of the late 20th century.

The cooking setup includes a rustic wood-and-metal support structure for the kettle, which directly sits over a fire built from logs. There's also an additional metal bucket positioned underneath the kettle, possibly catching drips or used for additional purposes related to the cooking process.

In the background, we see a rough, gravel-covered ground leading into a treed area, suggesting a rural or semi-rural setting. The environment is daytime with natural lighting that highlights smoke rising from the cooking area and the natural setting around the boy.

Overall, the photograph captures a moment of traditional outdoor cooking, possibly during a family or community gathering, emphasizing a hands-on approach to preparing a meal.
title: Youngster sprays water on boiling peanuts in Helen, Georgia near Robertstown. Helen was a typical small mountain community 90 miles northeast of Atlanta until early 1969 when local officials, the business community, and residents enthusiastically endorsed Renovation of the business district with a Bavarian alpine theme. Property valuation in the village of less than 300 residents was $1,484,775 in 1970 and had increased to $3,364,703 in 1974.
